1. Recycling one aluminum can save enough energy to run a TV for three hours.

 2. We consume over 80 trillion aluminum cans every year.

 3. Each year, Americans throw away 25 trillion Styrofoam cups.

 4. During the time it takes you to read this sentence, 50,000 12-ounce aluminum cans are made.

 5. Every day, American businesses generate enough paper to circle the earth 20 times!

 6. Recycling a single run of the Sunday New York Times would save 75,000 trees.

 7. On average, ONE supermarket goes through 60,500,000 paper bags per year!

 8. The amount of wood and paper we throw away each year is enough to heat 50,000,000 homes for 20 years.

 9. Americans use 2,500,000 plastic bottles every hour, most of which are thrown away.

 10.A modern glass bottle takes 4000 years or more to decompose.

 11.About one-third of an average landfill is made up of packaging material.

 12.Rainforests are being cut down at the rate of 100 acres per minute.

 13.If you walk a mile along an average US highway, you will see, on average about 1,457 pieces of litter.

 14.An automatic dishwasher uses less hot water than doing dishes by hand by an average of six gallons less per cycle, or over 2,000 gallons per year.

 15.More than 20,000,000 Hershey's Kisses are wrapped each day, using 133 square miles of tinfoil. All that foil is recyclable.

 16.Plastic soda rings, "baggies," styrofoam particles and plastic pellets are often mistaken by sea turtles as authentic food.

 17.Recycling just 48 cans is the energy equivalent of conserving one gallon of gas.

 18.One pound of newspaper can be recycled into 6 cereal boxes or egg cartons.

 19.Homeowners use up to 10 times more chemical pesticides per acre on their lawns than farmers use on crops.

 20.The more waste there is, the more pollution there is to handle, in the air, water, and the land.

Harry the Heap, the recycling robot, knows and he’s excited to show you the importance of recycling, safe waste disposal, and making choices for a sustainable lifestyle. Climb in our garbage truck and explore with Harry as he guides visitors in learning what “going green” really means. Other exhibit areas will demonstrate sources of alternative energy, the science behind landfills, the value of composting, and the energy required to light our homes. Learn about your carbon footprint and your impact on the environment.

Harry, a fully-animated robot, spends his days rapping about recycling and encouraging visitors to Go Green! This robot motivates people of all ages, especially children, to help the environment in any way, and there are a lot of ways. This character was created to better educate people in an amusing and harmless way about all the hazards to the enviroment, and how one person can "go green". This basically means the 3 R's, reduce, reuse, and recycle!

This image portrays how important recycling and "going green" is. It shows all the different types of material and which may need to be recycled or diposed of properly. Basically, this will create pollution and recycling, reusing, and reducing will definitely alleviate that!
